author: {'steamid': '76561198283106124', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1480521815}
review:
啊啊啊啊啊啊啊啊啊！太棒了TAT玩完真的意犹未尽！找个时间写细评，反正先给好评了！有机会的话二周目录个视频！
12/1
♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥这是可爱的分割线
[strike]《智障女神与妹控哥哥的神秘城堡》[/strike]是一款RPGmaker游戏，其中优秀的人物设定，鲜活的角色形象，以及精彩的场景演出都能给玩家在短短的游戏时间中留下不少美好的回忆。
游戏前期采用的是简明易懂的探索式开场，你既不知道你是谁，也不知道你从哪里来，你只知道你要去哪里。
为什么知道要去哪里？一是只有一条路，二是一开始仅有的一个npc告诉你不要走进那条路233333
没有多余的对话，没有多余的场景，直接进入地下城讨伐怪兽。
所以，前期这种潜移默化的系统引导其实是很不错的。很多优秀游戏比如塞尔达（虽然我没玩过）都是这种形式。
战斗系统其它评测里面有仔细讨论的，我就不多说了。因为不同怪兽的进攻方式不同，玩起来反而能感受到不少的策略感。（后面那个岩石怪的蓄力阶段无敌以及英雄的反甲简直惊了）
然后说到主人公，你控制的是这个城堡的女神。身体能力超强，从弓到剑到斧头（有吗？）样样精通；精神素质过硬，从雷电魔法到治愈魔法样样熟练。
唯一不足的是智力
跟别人说话只有一个呆萌的表情和
！OR ?
所以对面总是莫名奇妙感觉自己被嘲讽了然后开始决斗，接着被女主打的落花流水。[spoiler] （英雄泥奏凯，我死在你手上三次了233）[/spoiler]
接着你玩着玩着就发现...主人公的性格竟然也能成为剧情推动的关键要素之一。（学到了）
后来你会碰到许多角色，无论是四大魔王，不死骑士等等，性格都很有趣。
人物设定真的很不错。
后期的时候有许多地方系统引导不是很明确
比如通往主线的关键道路竟然隐藏在墙壁上...我看了别人的攻略视频才知道怎么走....（其实有提示...但是那里我看得确实不是很懂）
最后无论的打英雄的时候的演出还是最后的演出都非常精彩，也提供了真结局与坏结局的分支。
最后地图教科书式的重新回顾也起到了增加剧情感染力和游戏时间的作用，很不错。
♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥这是可爱的分割线
总评
+优秀的人物设定
+精彩的场景演出
+可爱的系统细节
+你能看到的武器基本都能用，包括敌人的。
-后期糟糕的系统指引
-部分npc的细节设定缺乏	[spoiler] （这一点很遗憾，比如镇长233）[/spoiler]
-音乐相比之前的优点有点欠缺[spoiler] （不过其实也很不错，并不是免费素材，诚意满满）[/spoiler]
________________
9/10
后记
[spoiler] 前面说的可爱的系统细节一个是一言不合吃牛排一个是女主的转圈★剪刀手，这个表情超级萌23333
其实女主有可能只是不善言语而不是智障
庆幸我是在undertale前玩的这个游戏2333不然可能评分会低一点，还有视频没时间录了，游戏买多了TAT[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198042494969', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1663899369}
review:
This is a deceptively simple game with an extremely fun battle system. It takes the turn based system of most rpgs and adds a timer to every attack, turning it into a much more strategic experience. You have to time your attacks so you can block damage when your opponents attack while landing damage when you do.

Enemies mostly have their own attack patterns, and will change things up to try and counter your moves. And so long as you're strong and skilled enough, you can beat virtually any foe without taking a scratch.

Boss fights are exceptionally creative, often times pushing you to your limits. And all of them are memorable.

The game is short, but charming. It starts out with you having no clue who you are or where you are. And as you progress, things start to make more sense. The ending itself is so fun, I've played this game an extra time or two just to enjoy it again.

This game costs only $2.00. It'd almost be a crime not to buy it. It goes WAY beyond what you'd expect to find from an RPG Maker game.

And just a pro-tip. About mid-way through the game, you can have a town's blacksmith upgrade your tools. Don't ask him to upgrade anything that you haven't upgraded to +9 already. Otherwise, you're just wasting your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313982497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1483632724}
review:
嘛，实在想不到第一篇评测居然会给这么一个RM小游戏而不是什么所谓的3A大作呢(笑)
进入正题。
强烈推荐。自打《东方年代记》以来第二款令我震撼的RM作品。
从几个方面来说一下吧：
[list]
  [*][h1]战斗方面[/h1]
[/list]
令人眼前一亮的战斗方式，读秒回合制的RPG玩过不知道多少，可是很少能像本作一样玩出这种花样的。不同武器的行动力消耗不一样，攻防也不同，是利用对手行动的空隙用行动快的弓迅速地展开rush？还是用攻防平衡的剑稳健的展开攻击？或是用等待时间长但期间防御薄弱的法术将对方轰杀至渣？别忘了，你的对手同样也深谙此道……抓住对方的弱点，隐藏自己的弱点，速攻还是持久战，多动脑子才能取得胜利。女主并不能通过不断的击杀怪物来变强，而是用经验值升级武器，在这给一个提示，别舍不得用经验值，游戏某些地方的boss和怪是有硬件要求的。还有，摁住shift可以奔跑。我能想到的唯一一个槽点：（以下黑条皆含有或多或少的剧透）[spoiler]我实在不觉得部分boss的血条隐藏是个好主意。四魔将那个还好一点，至少可以说是boss特性，至于后面的灰血条给人一种的恶心感。明明需要玩家掌握尽可能多的资料然后思考进行下一步的行动的，却又限制这种资料的给予。矛盾。[/spoiler]
[list]
  [*][h1] 剧情方面[/h1]
[/list]
令人惊叹。千万不要被开场完全没有交代的故事背景，不识字且只会说“？”的女主，劝告女主不要去探险却又在女主被打倒后把女主背回来的哥哥[spoiler]（？）[/spoiler]这些表象所迷惑住，随着剧情的推进，以某件可选事件为契机，可能会让你对开始的这种令人摸不到头脑的设定刮目相看。“啊，这样一切就都解释的通了……”这样的感觉。[spoiler] 还有，身为魔物的大家都有一颗金子般的心呢。从镇长的小考验，再到故意放水的魔王和骷髅剑客，封印明明那么脆弱，现任勇者也远远不及当年的勇者强大，可是大家却依旧努力维持着这种平静，最终boss虽然强大而野心满满，不过只要大家合力就能无往不利。还有悬疑的设置，正当一切全部按着计划进行，女主顺利的打败了放水的魔王和骷髅剑客，马上就能离开城堡的时候，勇者突然杀到，看起来像是正派人物的他却直接打废了本来给女主乘坐的狮鹫，因为女主“看上去不是魔物”才放了她一马，接下来女主醒来前去追勇者的时候，作者的剧情铺设功底体现得淋漓尽致：封死各个阶层快速往返女主的家的通路，使得玩家只能玩家只得一个阶层一个阶层往回走，迷宫中的怪物……全部消失了，城镇中的大家……也都消失了……因为勇者，是来[b]退治魔物[/b]的……虽然这最后不过是虚惊一场，勇者是正直的，不过这里的悬疑营造确确实实是一个不可能被忽视的闪光点。[/spoiler]
[list]
  [*][h1] 难度梯度[/h1]
[/list]
总体来说还可以。不过快到结尾的时候貌似难度梯度出了一些问题：能过最终boss的配置，却过不了顶层那条巨龙和魔像小兵。虽然有可能那里面的道具是用来打隐藏boss用的，不过我觉得这么设定还是有点问题。
[list]
 [*][h1]其他细节[/h1]
[/list]
女主的pose很萌，也是解决一个谜题的关键。[spoiler] 四魔将的台词貌似会随着打败他们的顺序而改变。如果不把被村长关起来的可怜人放出来而直接打败魔王的话会怎么样呢……？我也没试过。女主其实是会说话的，用？和！恐怕只是表述方便而已吧……？[/spoiler] 从底层追勇者的时候，背后的妖精会随着阶层的进行来改变台词。通关之后，各地都安插了吐槽役。最终的五连战里可以操纵之前的boss角色来进行其中的一些对战，[spoiler]让大家了解到不放水的boss们的真正强度，同时[/spoiler]扮演boss痛打杂鱼的感觉真是爽爆了。美中不足：通关后不能存档真是遗憾。打最终boss的五连战中间没有可以整备的机会，万一打到最后一战发现以目前的装备水平并不能击败最终boss，还得重新再打之前四战和一大段剧情。

就以上这些吧。大段的黑幕真是抱歉，不过黑幕后的内容真的都涉嫌剧透 [spoiler]虽然我知道你们肯定都刮开看了对吧[/spoiler]。
另外这个价格绝对物超所值。不要犹豫赶快入手吧。
最后写一些提示给我当时卡住的部分好了：
①、在别人安安静静读书的图书馆里打打杀杀来回乱跑可真是太没礼貌了。Helen不能做这么没教养的女孩子。
②、第二层很难走吧？如果实在不知道如何到达第一层，就先去寻找本层的档案室来获取提示吧。
③、图书馆里的宝箱，把心静下来耐心等一会，比不停地推门撞门好多了。
④、那些蜥蜴战士和桶一样沉。
⑤、有人模仿了你的脸可他不能模仿你的面。利用上等老坛拉开模仿者和你的差距，亦或是直接一拳打烂他的头。

最后的最后，像本作中唯二的受难者，狮鹫（弟）和某只可怜的羊致以最崇高的敬意。

author: {'steamid': '76561198200875926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1486578374}
review:
I am rather pissed off about this game. Its cheap (and I don't mean the price) and unfair. You fight the damn skeleton at the beginning after he knocks out half your health in one hit if he doesn't kill you in two, go restore your health at the only available spot outside, come back in and...oh would you look at that, the skeleton is back again blocking the door so he can take off half your health or kill you again, so you have to go back outside to restore your health, so he can come back and do it again. You get no potions, no other means of getting health back aside from a steak that gives you 1 extra HP. Big whoop. How about a five-course dinner that gives you a thousand HP, since you'll need that much to ever get past the second floor of the Dungeon of Death.

Oh, and there's that nice unavoidable monster that runs in on the next floor after you get the thunder ability, which he then promptly takes from you after he picks his teeth with Helen's balsa wood bones.

To the creator of this game, what the hell were you thinking?

author: {'steamid': '76561198084617081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1483186391}
review:
When you start up the game, you're kind of thrown into the world without much explaination or background to the story, which might throw some people off, but everything gradually unfolds as you play; I think the idea was that you're playing as Helen, who doesn't know much, herself, and as she learns new things, you learn along with her.

Throughout the game, you're given a lot of save file slots, which you may or may not use--you're also limited on how many items you can carry with you and forced to drop some in order to get others.  That might be concerning at first, but the game is easily playable without a guide, while still maintaining a sense of challenge.  [spoiler]Additionally, you'll find later that you can always reobtain what you've previously discarded[/spoiler], which is really nice and allows for more variety and experimentation. 

Overall, the game was really fun and has a nice story; I really enjoyed all the cute moments in the game.  The ending was really well done and wrapped things up nicely, giving you the option to revisit some of the places and people you've been to or met, before.  Don't be thrown off at the low price, either; it's one of the better rpgmaker games out there and I wouldn't have minded paying more than I did for it.

Also: If you like to savescum, F12 takes you back to the title screen without having to close the game. [spoiler]And after the last boss, you can retry without having to reload.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198216603937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1690093413}
review:
首先这是非常棒的一款RPG游戏。
你能在这里面找到一切优秀RPG的亮点：优秀的剧情，充满策略性让人欲罢不能的战斗系统，明快的演出……以及临场感十足的音乐。

然而比以上更重要是，也许初看上去这只是一款短小的城堡探险类RM RPG游戏。然而当剧情逐渐揭开面纱的时候，越来越多让人意想不到的展开浮现在你面前……说更多恐怕就会涉及到剧透啦，总而言之，这个故事绝非你想象中的那么简单哦。
这是一个短小精湛的游戏，完美通关+打通隐藏迷宫也不过短短6小时左右。但这丝毫不影响这是一个伟大的游戏的事实。

哪怕称之为有史以来最优秀的RPG游戏之一也不为过。
如果在即将来临的2017年你还没有体验过，那恐怕是你人生中的一个损失——这丝毫不夸张。

PS：中文化补丁已有网友制作完成，请搜索引擎输入“海伦的不可思议之城 汉化”。

满分，强烈推荐。

author: {'steamid': '76561198196129483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1482942150}
review:
首先，我还没有打完，但是一定一定一定要推荐一个汉化：

http://www.saraba1st.com/2b/thread-1355794-1-1.html

就凭这个汉化对魔王语气的把控程度，非常非常传神。

————————————————————————————

虽然第二天要去实验室，但还是忍不住一口气玩完了。

诚实地说，在废都物语之后，我还是第一次玩到这么优质的RPG，是不是画面粗糙的游戏都是剧情非常好啊——居然还有了这种感想。

这是个很慢热的游戏。主角一开始不识字，没有世界观、读不了书架上的书，只有一个绿头发还不知道是男性还是一个英俊的女性告诉你“不要去那个遗迹，很危险”，我在这个不识字的阶段捡起又放下捡起又放下，这基本上是这游戏前四个小时我干的事。直到耐着性子打过了狮鹫来到了小镇子，走剧情打到了魔王和他的四大天王的时候才觉得这个作者真有意思，官方吐槽实在非常非常有趣。

到后来剧情可谓急转直下，虽然到了中后期能够阅读书籍开始就大概能猜到走向，但是结尾还是小小地出乎了一下我的意料。[spoiler]“他也是我们的父亲啊”实在是……其实这一点也很有趣，魔法师嚷嚷着“怎么，难道你们也有了感情吗，明明只是魔物”的时候，他自己创造出来的魔物也是有了感情啊。[/spoiler]

打开二周目再次听见让海伦不要去北面遗迹这句话的时候，还是觉得非常温暖。

[b]9/10，除了跑地图太累和一直在麻痹之间过不去第二条门之外，就我个人而言无可挑剔。[/b]



另外，关于一些可能卡关的地方：
[spoiler]1.去找幽灵骑士的时候，在一个有哈比和野猴子的地方，应该在回去被哥哥教语言的楼梯附近的一张地图，靠墙处有一条密道，从密道走可以到达地图的右方，那里可以找到幽灵骑士继续剧情。

2.第一次去找哥哥的时候，回到家里，北面的墙上有一条密道，仔细找找就能发现。

3.结局的时候回到2所在的位置即可。[/spoiler]

最后的最后，如果有像我一样不在乎游戏性，只想看剧情的人的话：
[spoiler]游戏没有加密，可以用RM2000将某一件武器的攻击和防御调到999，等待调成1。这么做的时候注意一下后期有一种怪物叫巫妖，技能是模仿，一不小心就会把自己弄死。[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198120313148', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1489187144}
review: Was thinking about buying this game for a while and didn't buy it sooner because I thought I would buy it and never touch it, I was wrong. This game reminds me of old games i used to play similar to this like Lufia or even Final Fantasy. The game kept me occupied for the day and has a pretty good story behind it. If you like RPGs than this game is almost a must. It's value is definetly more than $2. If you like speedrunning, this game seems like a good game to do so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281792625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1482821009}
review:
[h1]想要触碰那天空与海水[/h1]

非常温柔的一个游戏，最温柔的莫过于那天空和海水。

+有趣的战斗系统，根据个人爱好可以有不同的战斗方式（一开始不知道可以升级武器卡了好久）
+简短的台词，却能塑造饱满的人物（好喜欢the undead knight，尤其是那个在看天空和海水的他）
+动人的音乐，最喜欢临近结尾处的那首原声，非常动人
+好美的天空和海水，感觉经费全用在天空和海水上了

-读档只能退出游戏

author: {'steamid': '76561198113276072', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1482901040}
review:
相当棒的游戏，相对于游戏的素质，我都觉得这定价有点低了
通关共用时5个半小时，包含隐藏迷宫全破，全收集
好久没有碰到这样让我一口气破关的游戏了，就一个字，爽
游戏设计的理念就不是一味的延长玩家的游戏时间，而是在相对短的游戏时间中提高玩家的体验，这点相当棒
顺便，本游戏汉化已出，请在S1论坛游戏区找，打个广告嘻嘻o(∩_∩)o

author: {'steamid': '76561198264770193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1484814694}
review:
有汉化啦~百度“不可思议之城的海伦”就能找到汉化
至于汉化导致的乱码请自行去系统字体里找到一个乱码字体，删除后就万事大吉了~
另外，这游戏超有趣，攻击方式啊，长时间停止不动会卖萌啥的，（隐藏图后能拿到马尾啊什么的）还有一些隐藏在奇怪的地方的房间都很有趣。不过值得注意的是：铁匠那边的等待是打怪，15只怪一次强化
小提示：
按X开菜单可以强化武器（虽然感觉这个都知道……不过貌似也有人不知道啊）
扔掉的东西可以无损拿回来，所以不要拿一把新的（对……我就是指不要强化了宽刃剑，丢掉后又回去拿了一把新的没强化过的……）
回复技能在战斗外回复会掉一个强化等级……（战斗内使用不会掉等级）
干脆利落的砸烂瓶瓶罐罐吧~有血量奖励哦！
能带8个装备而不是6个
第一个地图的那把长剑SS后可以用通关！（就是那个骷髅堵路的哪张图）
一定剧情后，可以经验升SS武器
SS猴子请拿勇者床边的盾

author: {'steamid': '76561198054177930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1561523534}
review: Muito bom! Esse jogo me fez sentir como quando joguei Final Fantasy pela primeira vez. Sempre com bons misterios e aventuras enquanto segue em frente. Com certeza vale a pena para qualque fã de RPGs de super nintendo, ainda mais por considerar o preço muito em conta do game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117584390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1482307759}
review:
Wow. It's been a while since I've played such a thoroughly charming and enjoyable retro RPG, especially running from RPG Maker.

Wonderful diversity of unique sprites and tiles, a simple (but sometimes tricky!) battle system, excellent soundtrack, and a great, feel-good story. $2.00 for this type of game is a downright steal, and I'd recommend [i] Helen's Mysterious Castle [/i] to anyone who likes turn-based strategy and a hearty serving of self-aware humor and charisma. I have to admit, there were a number of times the game's characters took me by surprise, and the world they live in is chock-full of secrets and items to find. There's even [spoiler] a sizeable amount of post-game content, and the challenge and charm only continues further from there [/spoiler].

I ran into just a few errors/technical issues during my full playthrough that I figured I'd mention:

[*] Entering the large door before the Castle Gate caused an error message once and closed the game. I tried it again, and it worked fine.

[*] Minor spelling errors. They didn't seem to appear until much later in the game, and by this point, I didn't care--I was having too much fun.

Developers, thank you so much for this game. [i] Helen's Mysterious Castle [/i] was an absolute delight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025500356', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 279, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1482258730}
review:
A one-party jrpg with simple but nifty combat system.

The gist of the gameplay is this: You're a one-girl dungeon explorer with various tools in your arsenal. Each weapons or spells have different stats, and "wait". Whenever you choose to use a weapon in the turn-based combat, both you and your opponent's wait countdown ticks down, until they reach zero, then the effect happens. So for example, if you use magic with 15 ticks wait, and enemy use dagger with 5 ticks wait, after 5 ticks the enemy attacks you, then they can choose another attack (since you're still in your magic casting). If they use another dagger attack, tough luck, in another 5 ticks they'll attack you again and you're still casting your magic.

It's simple, makes sense, smart, and fun. You try to strategize what weapon should you use this turn, should you use this long-casting magic spell that put your defense to zero but you think can down the enemy in one hit? This sword that is weaker but at least have some defense? Or should you put up your shield and try to find opening in your enemy's assault?

At first it might feel too simplistic or boring, but later when both your weapons and the enemies get more diverse, it get more fun.

And tha'ts not counting the simple but charming look of the game.

Not sure how long this game last, but with this price, it definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061365627', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 856, 'last_played': 1659054236}
review:
For someone like me, who generally shrugs off RPGs, I like to everynow and then shake things up and headplant into games whose category are not my forte at all, and rarely am I ever surprised.
[B]Helen's Mysterious Castle[/b] though, left me pleasantly surprised.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
For what it sets out to do, its pretty [b]decent and straight-forward[/b] i'll try to avoid the fact that the genesis of it is [b]VERY similar[/b] to a certain taleUnder, but nontheless, its effective, easy to grasp and fairly original.

[h1][b]Writing[/b][/h1]
Is strikingly ironic that this point is still here taking on account how the heroine is absolutely, entirely, possitively, incapable of reading or talking, is not like the game is Le Graveyard though, this game has something of a NINTENDO Syndrome, the main character is a mute, but the world around you does a great job with information and chatters.
For a RPG though, there's not much character development, with one expection mind you.
Overall, [b]Simple, but effective[/b].

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
Okay now, this is the part I tend to hate the most about [b]RPG[/b]s, Turn-based gameplay I tend to find silly and too restrictive for my tastes, however, this game manages to [b]Brilliantly handle RPG tropes with a very unique spin to the Turn-based formula[/b].
You have the standard Weapons, Items, Enhancing and all that good jazz, but this game manages to simplify core elements of RPGs, while tuning them to be equally engaging and easy to understand, special mention to the [b]Wait[/b] system, which introduces a large pool for optimization and a risk-reward formula.
The way [b]EXP[/b] is handled is very effective for quick-learners while also cutting down tremendously on the usual Grind factor of a RPG, along-side the depth of the [b]Wait[/b] system, makes for [b]a very free-flowing and enjoyable, still strategic combat[/b], you even get to experience playing with enemies' moveset and stats for a short time! [b]I fuᴄking love that![/b]
Only gripe I truly have is the abundance of [b]Defense Ignoring[/b] attacks, it [b]kinda breaks the game on both ways[/b], but you'll get used to telegraph them or maximize them.

[h1][b]Graphics[/b][/h1]
To put it bluntly, [b]Delightful[/b].
The landscapes you travel in range from Lively gardens to Lost ruins, all of them bringing absolutely amazing amounts of graphical detail and appeal, in-battle, making basic actions or even when posing during the Menu, everything is detail and animated silky smoothly.

[h1][b]Soundtrack[/b][/h1]
Have this analogy, its [b]like fast food, is amazing while having it, but is fairly easy to forget afterwards[/b].
The composition is mostly atmospherical, holding onto enough head-bopping traits to make it catchy.
However, with the two exceptions being [spoiler]Demon King[/spoiler] Castle and [spoiler]Hero Zack[/spoiler]'s Battle Theme, I can't really hum it by memory, that doesn't mean is bad, it just isn't infectuous.

[h1][b]Duration[/b][/h1]
As games made on Game Maker would have dictated by now, pretty short, [b]5 Hours tops[/b].
[b]DON'T LET MY PLAYTIME DECIEVE YOU[/b], It wasn't for the adventure itself, it's just that this game seriously [b]LOVES FAKE WALLS[/b], Two of them being related to Story progression with one not having any hint, so watch out.

[h1][b]tl;dr[/b][/h1]
Getting this game for only 2$ is literally robbery, the fun this game will provide deserves atleast a few bucks more, if you are a fan of [b]RPG[/b]s, definitely add this to your Collection, [b]if you are not a fan, get it anyway[/b], it offers great accesibility while not hand-holding you, [b]its a great entry-level RPG that doubles as a sufficient for RPG aficionados![/b]

[b]As such, I grant this game the mysterious...[/b]

[h1][b][u]Menu[/u] [u]Winks[/u] / [u]10[/u][/b][/h1]

[strike]no srsly helen winks when you are in the item menu, is fuqin adorable[/strike]

author: {'steamid': '76561198040578523', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 2362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1202, 'last_played': 1708729966}
review:
If you like RPGs, you owe it to yourself to pick up this game. For $2 it's an absolute steal.

And now, here's why!

Put simply, Helen's Mysterious Castle avoids most of the pitfalls common in RPGs throughout the ages- it even avoids the ones that Undertale falls into across repeated playthroughs. This isn't to say that it's a perfect game or that it avoids every pitfall, because it doesn't. But what it does do is avert a lot of expectations about the genre in very cleverly done ways.

Don't like random encounters? Good! Like Chrono Trigger, enemies wander around the various dungeons and battles only trigger on running into them. However, the enemies also move around in different patterns depending on the enemy. Cerberus will lunge at you at a high speed, Skeletons won't move, some enemies will move much faster if they notice you, and so on. This results in a very streamlined experience where you fight the battles you want to fight, or fail to avoid. Throughout the game there are very few forced non-boss encounters and these alone give you enough XP to beat the game, if you're careful.

Grinding is greatly alleviated and Helen has a very incremental rate of progression. Rather than leveling up on obtaining enough XP, you decide which weapons to level up with your experience. This can be done at any time, and poses some interesting strategic decisions. Do you level everything equally to be prepared for everything, or do you specialize in one or two attacks and hope that it's enough to take down everything in your path? The balance here could stand to be a little better, as the Blacksmith you encounter about a third of the way through the game can refine equipment 1 level beyond what Helen can, and the LongswordSP shatters game balance to the point where I highly suggest avoiding it. Other SP weapons are perfectly fine for balance, though.

As for the weapons throughout the game, there's a very solid mix. All attacks have three stats, and optionally a bonus effect such as piercing (ignores defense) or draining HP. These stats are Effect, Defense, and Wait. This results in a very simple system similar to Paper Mario where every attack has a predictable damage output, while also adding a huge layer of tactical planning that turns most boss encounters into puzzles. How can you exploit their moveset to create an opening to attack without leaving yourself open? This gameplay was very engaging to me and I played through the entire game in one sitting, taking about 5 hours.

Damage dealt is Effect of attacking move - Defense of defender's move. The tactical aspect comes in with the Wait stat- everything has one, and attacks only happen when the counter hits 0. If you cue up a Thunder spell, you'll be waiting a lot of ticks and any enemy with a fast attack will be free to wail on you during the cast time. This can sometimes feel a little bit like trial and error early on when you don't know how enemy attacks work, or what attacks a given foe has at their disposal, but Helen's Mysterious Castle allows you to save anywhere, at any time. Some battles do feel a little like there's One Right Choice for your loadout, but the sheer size of Helen's potential armory can make replays fresh, and with grinding being entirely optional, the battles don't get old even when they start playing out the same way every time. This simple system adds a ton of replay value by making the best choice at any given time dependent on what you're holding, and what your opponent is doing.

Many battles have creative gimmicks to them that can force you to change your entire strategy; one removes your current attack as an option for the rest of the battle, several poison you at the start which makes you take 5 damage after your every action, several can lower your max HP within the battle, some will make your next attack take longer to execute, one notable case will reflect all damage blocked... the list of creative gimmicks goes on and on. Every boss feels unique and fresh, which is a marvel for how overall simple the systems involved are. Helen's Mysterious Castle is definitely a case of real complexity through fewer meaningful choices. This is compounded by the fact that Helen can only carry 8 pieces of equipment at a time- anything dropped can be picked back up at a specific area opened fairly early on in the game.

On the topic of replay value: the longest cutscene in the game is about a minute long, barring the final boss gauntlet of the good ending. Again, this neatly dodges the common issues of RPGs having more dialogue and cutscene than gameplay these days. What gameplay there is, as mentioned, is only as tedious as you want it to be. The final boss gauntlet is even very nice in that it autosaves between each of the battles, instead of making you sit through the cutscene and refight any bosses you've already beaten. So many RPGs make you do this, it's kind of absurd! It doesn't hurt that the soundtrack throughout the game is always a good listen and always an amazing fit. Everything from the hanging gardens boss onwards is amazing, and while testing speedrun strategies for the last bosses of both the good and bad ending, the soundtrack never got old. And I was testing strategies for over an hour on the good ending gauntlet!

Let's see... I suppose I should mention the story. There really isn't much of one, and the characters don't stick around too long or develop much. But this is an otherwise small blemish on an otherwise fantastic game: especially since the small story manages to throw in a couple surprising twists even to longtime fans of the genre. Even I fell for the fake ending, and I can usually see through those a mile away.

Oh and I mentioned speedruns of this earlier- everything it averts above makes it a very fun RPG run with very little downtime. It fit everything I'd been looking for in an RPG speedrun, and I played it because I was looking for a short RPG to play through. I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I did, but I'm very glad I gave it a play soon after picking it up.

In conclusion: Helen's Mysterious Castle is a fantastic experience for any RPG fan, new or old. Newcomers will enjoy the simple systems and the depth they create, while longtime fans will appreciate everything it does differently from the norm. Just don't play with a key rebinding utility open- this can cause some strange bugs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018978285', 'num_games_owned': 467, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1480364173}
review:
A simple and rather compact RPG with a very wellmade battle system that reminds me a bit of Riviera: The Promised Land.
It stripped away the tediousness of Riviera's stat grinding and replaced the classic level up system.
Instead of levelling your character, you level your equipment and this actively influences your chances in battle.
Because the game and difficulty is dependent on your usage of your equipment, the grind for more exp is really just a measure to make the already manageable difficulty more feastable for less experienced players.

The battle system is easy to understand and if enough thought is put into practice, this battle system is also easy to exploit. The really good aspect of the battle system is that you and your enemy are using the same battle system to defeat each other, with many different types of enemies taking a different approach to how they outplay you. This comes clear in the latter half of the game when enemies will actively try to punish you for misplays or for your potentially one-sided inventory.

For me personally, it's the boss battles that were really thrilling in Helen's Mysterious Castle. A whole lot of different play mechanics were brought into battle that bosses incorporate in their play but the mechanics still feel fair in terms to the battle system. Many players fill their inventory with their unique blend of equipment combinations, making the game feel really refreshing if you decide to use different equipments on your second playthrough.

What this game could have done better would be to include a general place to get tips and advice on how to proceed. On three occasions the game tried to artificially lengthen your playtime by obscuring your next tasks. You actually need to backtrack and check for information, find secret passages based on what was told by an NPC / written on a bookshelf or do specific things infront of objects - all in order to proceed.

I bought the game for 140cents, definitely worth the price. Don't take the game for "just another RPG maker game".

author: {'steamid': '76561198290327465', 'num_games_owned': 902, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1527192117}
review:
My favorite thing about this game is how little randomness is involved on the battle system. The way enemies react lets you plan ahead your strategy, so if you die you know it is your fault. Plus the story is nice and the price is fair.
I guess the default assets may turn some people away, but if gameplay is more important then it is worth giving it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059941307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1626602845}
review:
Bist du Fan von Old School JRPGs? Wie Final Fantasy, Golden Sun, oder eines der vielen anderen?
Dann ist dieses Spiel einen Bilck wert.
Es ist sowohl ernst, als auch lustig. Ist zwar mit dem RPG Maker gemacht, und hat deshalb ein paar kleine Mängel, aber diese sind so minimal, dass man über sie hinwegsehen kann.
Und das Ende ist ... um es in einem Wort zu beschreiben "Zucker". Besser als alle AAA Titel der letzten Jahre.
Das Kampfsystem ist etwas anders, als man es von JRPGs kennt, aber hat es hat seinen eigenen Charme.

Es kostet 3 Euro (im Sale noch weniger) und man bekommt 5 Stunden Spielspaß. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046408318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1512825130}
review:
Recomendaria para qualquer um. Principalmente com um preço tão pequeno quanto esse. 

Pequeno e charmoso RPG. Com uma historia simples e muito bonitinha sobre o passado de uma garota e o castelo onde ela esta. Apesar de um inicio lento a historia se desenvolve de maneira agradavel sem deixar ser interessante.

Seu sistema de batalha é unico e genial. você usa sua experiencia apenas para melhorar suas armas e não seu personagem. O que torna todas as lutas interessantes, ja que se você bobear pode perder quase qualquer uma delas. Cada tipo de monstro é uma especie de puzzle novo que você tem que aprender a lutar.

Porem o jogo pode ter muito grind (ficar matando monstro pra pegar experiencia) principalmente se você quer pegar todas as armas e acessorios. E algumas armas em lv alto são fortes D+ comparado a outras.

Essa pequena, calorosa e meiga experiencia ficara marcada em mim para sempre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040984934', 'num_games_owned': 1192, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1478904434}
{'steamid': '76561198053712077', 'num_games_owned': 2406, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1563380145}
review:
Helen's Mysterious Castle is a short, simple RPG that excels at what it does.

You play the titular Helen, a mute girl in a castle, which you'll eventually learn all about. The thing that got me into this game was the combat system; once you learn it, you can employ it to the best of your knowledge and nothing can stand in your way, maybe except the post-game bosses. Even so, it feels good.

It's cheap, story's decent, and if you really want to see if it's for you, go watch some combat gameplay, since you'll be doing a lot of that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188664927', 'num_games_owned': 1605, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1708095429}
review:
[quote]Follow my Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41363546-Fruit-N-Doggie-Reviews/]Fruit N Doggie Reviews,[/url] so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.[/quote]
[h1]Overall Rating - High Quality ★★★★☆[/h1]

[h1]First Impressions[/h1]
I can't believe it's been so many years since I touched Helen's Mysterious Castle (HMC), but that just shows how quickly time slips away. It's an RPG Maker game, but the developer created mechanics that involved a bit more work than what you might see in 100 other titles. You still have a modest, short RPG, yet if you're tolerant of indie experiences, it may be worth checking out.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
HMC gives a nice twist to what can be a repetitive combat system in most turn-based RPGs. Each move has three stats – attack, defense, and cast time. Attack shows how much damage the move does, defense will resist that much damage from an enemy, and cast time reflects the amount of time it'll take to activate. As you progress, you will have as many as eight options to choose from in any given situation, and have to predict what actions the enemy will take. 

If you play too defensively, they might use an attack that ignores your defenses. If you play too aggressively, they might use fast, weak attacks while you're vulnerable. Fast attacks have a good chance to hit, but when the enemy is blocking, it won't do anything. This makes even simple enemies potentially dangerous, since each move has pros and cons, and you'll have to adapt for each enemy. For this reason, this is an RPG where you are likely to die, as a new enemy you don't know how to handle can outmaneuver you. However, "death," is lightly punished, and sometimes causes an HP boost. I'm not positive what conditions lead to that though. 


[h1]Controls[/h1]
After double-checking, I was pleased to see that this game is compatible with my controller. Interestingly enough, it's another recent example where the Start button was used for one of the inputs, instead of something more straightforward. Otherwise though, everything seemed to work just fine.


[h1]Story[/h1]
Initially, Helen is illiterate, which isn't something I ever think about with games. No matter the time period, most characters are educated enough to read, even if that wouldn't be likely. This impacts some early mechanics, since she can't read any signs, books, or other interactive elements you'd normally have no problems with in a game. As you explore and advance in this adventure, her naivete is made more clear as you find out about how this place works and what's going on. At a certain point, you'll even start questioning whether you're in a castle at all.


[h1]Visuals[/h1]
When looking at RPG Maker games, this is the main area where you'll notice where the title was designed. The point of the engine is to supply the materials needed to make a game without as much pain as starting from scratch, and part of that comes down to the building blocks in its visuals. It's definitely better than other examples, where enemies and other assets are just copy and pasted without any effort. Despite that, nothing really stands out or impresses me with how HMC looks. The enemies and characters are fairly standard looking.


[h1]Sound Design[/h1]
Having played some RPG Maker games, I wouldn't know whether the track here come from a song list, or if they were composed specifically for HMC. They're decent quality tunes either way, helping make the playthrough more enjoyable. However, even though the battle track is solid, it does get repetitive throughout the game's duration since it's the same no matter what enemy you fight. In some ways, the longer battles almost works against the song, as it'll mean you hear the same tune so many times. Looking at another matter, when your attacks land, they have a surprisingly impactful sound effect. I prefer that to a weak, barely noticeable noise though. Thankfully, they also aren't aggravating or annoying.


[h1]Pros[/h1]
🌟 Boss battles are more interesting than normal, because they aren't just bullet sponges. Instead, beating them revolves around learning their moves and properties, having to find the right strategy to outwit them.
🌟 Instead of leveling up from fighting enemies, you'll use those experience points to upgrade your equipment. It's not original, but is still a nice alternative to the conventional approach.
🌟 Dying in some games can be punishing, but it's not much of a set-back in HMC.


[h1]Cons[/h1]
❌ Even if the mechanics are different, you can still tell it's an RPG Maker game. There's just some inherent limitations from that.
❌ Some secrets were a bit cryptic or random, as I didn't see any hints to check that area, I just tried every part of the wall.


[h1]Tips[/h1]
🔍 When fighting the same enemy type, their AI tends to be consistent. IE, learn how to defeat them once, and the same approach should always work.
🔍 If you do get stuck, try another approach with different moves. Alternatively, a bit of grinding should be enough to get you through.


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
Over time, I've gotten a bit jaded on RPG Maker games. Sometimes they can be surprisingly decent, but there seems to be a general pattern for those exceptions. They alter the mechanics so it isn't merely a turn-based RPG where you can mindlessly spam basic attacks. HMC does that, making each battle require some focus as you manage the three stats of each move. It's about the right length for an indie RPG, and has an interesting story as well. I didn't necessarily love some of the secrets, but I suppose that fits the idea of the castle being mysterious. 

Unless you find yourself intrigued by the mechanics or have enjoyed other RPG Maker games, even at $2, I wouldn't buy it. The game is decent, but it wouldn't change your perspective on RPG Maker titles. For those who are alright with a shorter RPG, with a focus on strategy and occasional secrets, I'd recommend picking it up. You'll find out pretty quickly whether it's your cup of tea or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127444181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1564627696}
review:
A great, unique, short and $2 game.
There... that's about all that can be said about it, in an instant I've gone over the pros of the game and given you a summary in one line.
Yes I have 11 hrs in the game and yes I've finished it twice now and do you know what? I've enjoyed every minute of it.
The unique thing that stuck out for me... and the unique thing that sticks out for everyone is the battling system, let me give a basic (If horrible) explaination of it.

There is a 'wait' attribute with every weapon, this dictates the amount of 'time' you must wait before damage is delt or for how long the item is active, for example the wooden sheild (First sheild in game) has a wait of 8, therefore the sheild is active for 8 'turns' (That's how I'll refure to it from now... okay?) however the 'thunder' spell (Again the first you get in the game) has a wait of 10, this means 10 turns pass before you attack with the spell.
This 'wait' also applies to enemies meaning the game get VERY tactical very quickly, especally in late game, which devolves to: Use most powerful spell in game, heal, sheild, sheild, sheild, use most powerful spell. Rince and repeat.
The final boss is HORRIBLE for this.

Now, lets talk something else, say maps...
While the overworld maps are very small and sometimes constrictive, they work. It is hard to explain why they work, but they do. There are your confusing ones, the ones you wish didn't exist, the "this is a perfect spot to grind" ones and a little town one. OH BOY! What varity.

The game is very short, a decent player can reach a clear in about three hours including grinding times, how ever I an not decent at this game, it took me NINE HOURS to reach a clear for the first time... not as bad as Suguri... 31 hrs and counting... still haven't finished it on easy...
Sigh... back to this game 'though.
It's brevity is good, in a portal way. You can tell whoever made the game was running out of default assets to use (Did I mention that this uses default assets? No) because not long before end game you have to backtrack through the ENTIRE MAP...(S) with the shortcuts cut off. THough the default assets can be put aside, mainly because of the combat system... and the fact it was made in RPG school (From the name I'm going to guess it's babbys first RPG Maker) the readme confirms this.

Story wise there isn't much to say, the brevity of the game means there is little time for telling of lore and such, however the story we have is solid, but has a tendency to introduce charactors at the last minutes unless you've been paying attention throught the entire game and have found all of the readable bookshelves.

So, here we are, the end of my review. There isn't much to say about a normal $2 JRPG, but this game is special, oh so very special. In it's combat, it's kind of stupid storyline and not to mention the maps (Yes I'm going to harp on about them... despite them being small... and sometimes kind of shit...)
So Pros and Cons... the poor mans TL;DR.

Pros:
Unique combat system

Wacky and stupid story that we all love.

Lots of hidden secret passages and such holding... sometimes powerful gear.

An enemy named 'What is this?'

Price tag

Cons:
Sometimes it's hard to get decent gear without being killed or knowing the maps and such.

One or two annoying parts (Namely one door I can not for the life of me figure out how to open, but somehow do. And one boss where you can't see their health bar or they're 'wait' timers or the stats of the attack they're about to use)

Small maps, the maps that exist are good, just EXTREMELY small... and sometimes hard to navigate.

Some gear can only be found once, for instace right before a boss fight when you shouldn't drop your good weapons but for completeionest sake you do anyway, admitently the particluar situation I'm talking about yeilds a rather good weapon with a great Debuf.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063505124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1490487215}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057263203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1484474101}
review:
After playing games like Wadanohara and LiEat that had amazing stories but were too easy combat wise, (as in you'd had to try and lose the battles) I've been looking for a new RPG Maker game that actually challenges you with fairly challenge and well balanced in difficulty fights. With this game, I got my wish.

Story:
Overall, it's a very simple story. You play as the silent protagonist Helen (literally, all she really says is "?" and "!" and stuff along those lines) as she is seeking to get to the first floor of the island to discover about her past and the world below. Along the way, she faces many challenges against different kinds of monsters. There isn't much too it until you finally reach the 2nd floor that the plot takes a surprising turn, but that is best saved for you to find out.

Characters:
Despite how simple the story is, I found the characters very likable. Helen despite being silent is simply adorable, and you'll find yourself attached to many such as the Undead Knight and the Demon King as well as Helen's brother. There isn't really much large character development, but I'd say it works for a very simple story.

Gameplay:
Unlike other RPGs, this game runs on fighting a single enemy each battle. The three stats are as followed:
Effect - How much damage you'll deal
Defense - Reduces how much damage you'll take through simple subtraction. If the Defense is higher than the Effect, unless there is a pierce effect, you'll take no damage.
Wait - How long before you take action.
The key here is use the multiple of weapons, armor, magic and tools you find to combat against the enemies you fight, since all of the enemies actions have a wait and the turn won't end until you attack. And example is fighting Slimes in the earlier stages of the game: You can get in two shortbow attacks before the are close to attacking with their command, so use the wooden shield after that to guard their attacks and negate the damage before launching the final attack you'll need to finish them. In addition, you can only have up to eight items at a time, so you will need to discard items to replace for different ones. This in term brings strategy to the game as you'll need to figure out how to combat enemies effectively as there will be points enemies can out-think you and will guard or perform a quick powerful magic attack while your preparing for a strong hit. As you get closer to the end, the enemies get smarter and more challenging, especially the bosses. In fact the bosses from the 2nd floor and to the end of the game are highly considered some of the hardest fights in the game. This game is short, but it's by no means easy if you can't think carefully. You will be losing a lot.

Final thoughts, it's a very short and simple story that will make you feel for many of the characters. But the battles can prove to be very difficult to the un-prepared compared to other games. I'd highly recommend it as it is ONLY $2. There are many different tactics you can use, and many hidden things to find.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971628333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1478156029}
review:
[b]A few negative quirks aren't enough to hold down a great combat system, cute characters and a succinct but charming story.[/b]

Let me begin with a few pointers that I wish I had known going into Helen's Mysterious Castle. First, fullscreen mode (accessed by holding Alt and pressing Enter) caused horrible stuttering on my system and I know I am not the only one. The best way around this that I found is by using Windows Magnifier. You can trigger this by holding the Windows key (between left Ctrl and Alt) and using the + and - keys to zoom in and out. By default it zooms in where your mouse cursor is located. On a 1440p monitor I found +325% zoom to be just right.

Second, the main character, Helen, is illiterate at the outset of the game. You can learn to read, but it is easy to miss and cannot be unlocked by backtracking late in the game. I'll spoiler tag the instructions, but this is a very, very minor spoiler: [spoiler]When you first unlock the second shortcut back to your home there will be a new gravestone nearby. Examine it for a cutscene where, among other things, Helen is taught to read.[/spoiler] If you don't do this you'll miss out on some nice tidbits of lore that help to more fully illuminate what's really going on in this mysterious castle.

The third and final tip: After fighting the Undead Knight, there seems to be a common game crash that is avoidable. It happens immediately after the battle when entering a double doored cathedral through the left door. The right door does not seem to be affected by this crash, but it's worth saving your game just in case.

[b]Now, on to the actual review.[/b]

This little gem of a game's brightest aspect is its battle system. Combat encounters are elegant duels that have you constantly switching tactics in order to counter your opponents moves. I will leave the details for you to discover on your own, but in short you have 8 inventory slots to fill from a collection of equipment that includes bows, swords, shields, various magics and passive stat boosting items. You will need to keep a diverse selection in order to be successful.

You find new items at a steady pace throughout the game. Many of them are in optional side areas. As you gain experience in the game, you do not level up yourself, but instead use your experience to upgrade your equipment. This grants a satisfying sense of progression that gives you frequent, small boosts in power.

The combat isn't entirely flawless though. First, fights are only ever 1 vs 1 affairs. The mechanics don't lend themselves well to having numerous participants. Second, once you've found a winning strategy against a particular monster, you can usually easily repeat the process on successive battles with that opponent type. This is both good and bad in that it rewards you for skillful play, while also making further battles less engaging. These are minor complaints that are largely counteracted by excellent boss encounters, many varying enemy types and the relatively short length of the game.

Uncovering details about this game's castle setting and its inhabitants is a joyful experience. You are set loose in the beginning with no exposition and only slowly learn the true nature of this place and its people. There are a few minor writing errors, but the script is otherwise skillfully woven in a way that, as more information is revealed, you can look back on some previous conversations and see deeper meaning in them. The story is often cute, relatively lighthearted and even comical at times but it is not without touching moments and serious topics. Visuals and sound commendably convey the emotions of the scenes, albeit in a familiar SNES RPG style.

In addition to being illiterate, Helen also speaks with only two symbols, "?" and "!". This gives the sense that she is also mute, making her hard to relate to as a character but easier to apply your own personality to. I didn't care for this design decision. Regardless of this, she does have a short but interesting past that's tied into the plot. Most other characters are enjoyable but the game isn't long enough to give them great depth. There is one character that I won't reveal the identity of that is the main focus of the story. We get to learn a lot about them, even more so if you unlock the ability to read.

I ended up playing through this game twice. My first playthrough took just over 6 hours to complete while the second was a little over 3 hours. I actually accomplished more the second time through despite taking half the time. Unfortunately this game is occasionally unclear with its directions on how to proceed. Two instances in particular had me lost for a significant amount of time before discovering that the way forward was through a hidden passageway. I only discovered these by mindlessly running into walls in the general area that I thought I was supposed to be in. I wouldn't call that good game design and it artificially pads the game length.

There is decent replay value to be found here. Trying out different equipment builds can be fun. There is enough hidden and optional content that you'll likely find new things the second time around. In the credits there is a hint on where to find the entrance to a dungeon with the hardest enemies you'll encounter in the game. There are even two endings (that I discovered, at least). One is definitely more satisfying than the other but it is easy enough to move from one to the other without replaying the whole game.

With such a low price tag this is an easy game to recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007177406', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1477833188}
review:
[u][b]A game that is more than worth its small price[/b][/u]

A pleasant length of around 5 hours of playtime, a unique and very fun leveling and battling system; a quirky, sometimes serious storyline, which doesn't take itself to serious for the most part.

This all topped of with above average looking sprites and memorable Hero and Boss Monster designs alike make this a cheap and short, but overall very positive experience, which I would have gladly payed a higher price for if demanded.

Should you require an arbitrary number to better understand how exactly I rate this game then I will herewith grant this game a [b] 8.5/10[/b] for the above mentioned reasons + the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037372051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1475894142}
review:
A really great little JRPG!

Helen's Mysterious Castle is simple, fun, short, and charming. It does what it does well and scratches all the right JRPG itches, with an awesome combat system that you can pick up in moments, yet which keeps on delivering depth throughout the whole 5-6 hour experience thanks to the plethora of unique items and interesting encounter designs. Much like the combat, the story starts off incredibly basic, yet manages to pull off an emotionally engaging ending by the time it's done. I have to give this game huge points for being so accessible and easy to pick up, unlike so many JRPGs that frontload slow paced story and tutorials. Helen's Mysterious Castle has enough confidence in its gameplay and tone to allow those parts to suck you in first, before layering on the narrative and mechanical complexity as the adventure unfolds.

The only noteworthy negative I encountered with the game was related to a section of backtracking, waiting, and moderate confusion at around the mid point, where the requirements for progression started straying into the "run around talking to everyone and examining everything to try and find the progression trigger"  ballpark. There are perhaps one or two other moments in which this might happen for some players when the progression path is unclear, and the lack of online walkthroughs for this game might result in a little frustration, but thankfully there is at least one commentary-free LP on youtube that should help anyone who gets stuck.

Aside from that, however, my time with Helen's Mysterious Castle was thoroughly enjoyable. The music is fantastic and enthralling, the storyline and characters are cute, the difficulty progression ramps up beautifully from smooth to challenging, and there's potentially a fair bit of replay value if you want to try and find all the hidden items and try out varying builds.

As far as simple, small-scale indie JRPGs go, this is one of the best I've played. A perfect game to drop a couple of bucks and a weekend on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056701760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1474457913}
review: I'll be honest, I didn't expect much when I bought this game. Just another cheap little indie RPG to add to the collection. But this game surprised me more than any other game I've ever played on here. I loved exploring and getting little glimpses of the world that this game created, I loved the game's battle system, which put a unique spin on turn-based battling that I have never seen used quite so well. The music was fantastic, there were plenty of secrets to discover, and the ending... I don't want to spoil anything, but this game's ending is by far my favorite ending of any RPG. What a rush! Buy this game, and I promise you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072231481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1688272225}
review:
Six or seven hours' worth of the most fun battle system I've ever seen in a JRPG. I was a BIT skeptical when I saw the stock RPG Maker 2000 graphics in the screenshots, but the characters are entertaining, the maps are excellent, there's plenty of easter eggs hidden in places you wouldn't expect them, and the story, while nothing extremely revolutionary, is enjoyable nonetheless.

But the main draw is definitely the battle system, which you learn in a dungeon designed to teach you through experience. The game, while certainly difficult, isn't out to murder your progress; you're sufficiently warned before any incoming boss fights, and if you do go down, you just end up at your house (or the inn), with a steak next to your bed that you can eat for a permanent HP boost.

My only complaint is a certain bug that might crash the game after the main boss of the second floor. Be sure to save after defeating the miniboss Soul Cage!

author: {'steamid': '76561198101604481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1472957176}
review: I absolutely LOVED this game. Adorable, entertaining, a little confusing at times. The mechanics are simple but unique and the story is more than what you expect it to be! I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a cute RPG to have some fun with.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999410762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1473624159}
review:
Helen's Mysterious Castle shines with charm and class.

Its story is minimal and affecting. It starts with no intro to speak of, dropping you straight into its world, then gradually unfurls. Little characters and moments are far more important than they initially appear. Short conversations endear you to its characters, so much so that you're sad when they're seemingly gone forever, and overjoyed when they return.

These narrative arcs elevate what's already a world-class dungeon-crawler. The level layouts are smart, economical, and dense. The one-on-one battles last under a minute a-piece, and pose extremely clever and engaging tactical challenges. It's a hard game at times, but also very kind -- death in battle poses no penalty except for sending you to the start of the dungeon, where you're given a meal that permanently raises your max HP.

The aesthetic builds on default resources with heaps of excellent custom sprites, animation, and reorchestrated music. For someone already delighted by the RPGMaker 2000 aesthetic, the effect is intoxicating. 

Helen's Mysterious Castle takes exactly the amount of time it needs to fully explore the greater realities of its combat and its characters. Then it ends, without wasting your time. It is a thoughtful and lovely game, and I look forward to revisiting it in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026452979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1473560611}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972347569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1515607109}
review:
Love it!
- The combat system is deceptively simple yet the more you play the more you realise how deep it can be, and how it gives rise to a wide variety of uniquely-feeling encounters. Combat feels tactile and strategic with only a few elements. Very clever.
- It's light on story and it doesn't take itself too seriously, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. The story gets out of the way and lets you focus on adventuring.
- Dungeons are small but densely-packed. You might die a few times, but you'll constantly be opening up shortcuts so getting back to where you died is a breeze.
- The music can get a bit repetitive. Oh well, not a big deal.
- And because I know some people will care about this: yes, it uses a fair few RTP assets, but it uses them well and there are loads of custom-made assets too. There's enough new stuff here to make it feel like its own thing. It doesn't really feel like an RPG Maker game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101656172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1474086374}
review:
非常好的轻策略RPG小游戏，所有设定都让人感到舒服

[spoiler] 除了最后的Krace，不知道怎么打（后来发现只是隐藏了血条...），反复BOSS RUSH耗了我大半个小时，玛德	[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198082339289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1473708314}
review:
A very fun RPG where there are no random misses or critical hits. Instead, each weapon has three stats and (in some cases) a special effect. The three stats are the time it takes to use the weapon, the defense bonus while the weapon is being used, and the damage dealt when the wait time finishes. Quick, flimsy attacks allow you to deal great damage when an enemy uses a low-defense weapon, and coordinating your wait times to use a heavy hitting weapon without getting hit are just two examples of how this battle system opens many unique encounters with new strategic opportunities.
You do not level up in this game. Instead, XP is spent on weapons to upgrade them. You can only have eight weapons at a time, so choosing an effective loadout is important. Don't worry about losing weapons you drop on the floor to get more inventory space: A room reachable fairly early in the game allows you to regain your dropped weapons, and they will still be leveled up!
The story is good at driving the action and motivating the player (especially toward the end of the game), but don't go into this game expecting it to be story-heavy, since the story is secondary to the battles.
Sound effects and visuals are the standard RPG maker type, but the sprites manage to be especially detailed and well animated. Music is good and decently varied.
I would give this game an 8/10. It's definitely worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025339818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1473646839}
review:
Green-haired dude(?): "Good morning, Helen. I made you a steak!"
Helen: *Looks around.* "WHERE'S MY F*****G STEAK?!"

WTF was that? There wasn't even an intro to the story. I was just thrown into a map with no f* clue of what to do, what the character's motivations, or even daily routine, are.
Man, Ive been trolled.

Now, in all seriousness: 

Your game's Steam store page has more story and explanations than the game itself. All of the things you explain in there, you should explain naturally within the game. At the least, start the player with an initial dialogue or some basic intro sequence.

Mechanics show potential, graphics are very cute, and so is the music. I just think you underdid the story and player-friendliness aspects, which are very important here, since you're actually selling the girl's story in the store page.

You're charging for this game. This feels like a game demo you would find in RMRK.net or some other RMRK community site, to be honest. If you are going to sell your game, show that at least you tried to make it worth our time and money (yes, even if it costs so little). That is my very honest opinion, as a consumer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021774673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1473439927}
review:
A cute little semi-turn-based game. Definitely worth the price.

It should be noted that reaching the end of the game requires finding two or three secret passaged.
If you find yoursel stuck, you're gonna want to walk into every wall you can find.

Overall I rate this a 7/10, but don't expect an epic journey. Helen's Mysterious Castle is relatively short, appropriately so for the complexity of its gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024602273', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1473481734}
review:
A very fun little game, with a heartwarming plot and fresh battle mechanics that work surprisingly well.

I highly recommend picking this up, there are a few problems with the game itself (couple of bugs and lack of direction at times) but I'll cover what I discovered here...

After defeating Mr Undead you will have to break the barrier, which is the the building to the north of where you entered that room from, if you enter on the left side of that door it might crash the game, so make sure to enter from the center (or maybe it was coincidence that it worked whe I entered through the middle, but hey, it worked for me!)

After you break the barrier, there is a extra bit of pathway on the top left behind the barrier, walk onto that square and move left to proceed to the next area! I spent 40 minutes going in circles around the dungeon trying to find a character with directions, heh.

anyway, a very good game for the price, doesn't take too long to beat (only took me 5 hrs) and I am hoping very much for a sequel. Also, if you enjoyed this, you might enjoy the labyronia rpg series, if you haven't already tried it, ty have fun :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198001378845', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1473257060}
review:
Helen's Mysterious Castle is a wonderful JRPG that I think everyone should try. It's inexpensive, most anyone can afford it, and despite being a JRPG you can easily finish it in 8-9 hours. It's short, but incredibly well put together, with a plot that, while not world-shattering with stakes so high that Dracula's in danger even in orbit, nonetheless is well executed and allows for things to focus on the character and the world they find themselves in. It also contains an excellent, innovative RPG combat mechanic that I've never seen anywhere else.

I give it 9/10 thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056482771', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1472861646}
review:
Good game
Sound track is great
Graphics look great
Combat is extreamly good. (If you are a numbers guy like me at least)
Good humor

Not real options AFAIK (F4 is to make it full screen and F12 is to reset the game to title screen)
Can get lost extreamly easily (Had to look up a guide 4 times)
Doesn't tell you how to upgrade weapons, which is extreamly important
Buttons could be a lot better, but are not terrible.

1.99 USD game. Got about 8 hours worth of game. Cheap and can have replay value for some (not much for me)

7/10 Good game over all but not perfect. Try it if you can.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986522424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1479960178}
review:
This was the most satisfying RPG that I've played since Cthulu Saves the World. If all RPG Maker games were this good, I'd be a very happy gamer.

The game is short, but it has got solid battle mechanics, secrets and easter eggs, good music, good graphics, likeable characters and story, and an attention to details like not annoying the player. None of the battles or animations drag on - the whole game is set up to be a rather seamless experience. The dev did good, period.

If you want more details, read the other reviews that get more in depth. I rarely review stuff, but this game deserved a review.

Would buy again at full price. (Unheard of for me.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198297929701', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1420, 'last_played': 1558728202}
review:
战斗系统很有意思——虽然与《最终幻想10》的CTB（Conditional Turn-Based Battle）本质上是一回事，但行动条件改为数字显示之后，战斗更具策略性了，有种在玩战棋游戏的感觉。

[strike]本游戏至今仍未有完整的中文攻略（Guide + Walkthrough + Secret），我一直想写一份。遗憾的是，本作似乎没能引起中文玩家的注意（连主题百度贴吧都没有注册），中文攻略也似乎派不上用场了。等有中文母语玩家需要了，我再写吧。
虽然"不看攻略自己玩"是一种乐趣，但那蹩脚的英文翻译与隐晦的通关指示/解谜提示，也许会让过关有些难度，浪费不少时间。

总的说，作为RPG Maker系的JRPG，本作的质量是出类拔萃的；尽管并未优秀到不可错过，但若说所有RPG Maker系游戏中只能推荐一款，我一定会选这款。

--------------------
乘着Steam大奖评选期，更新一下这份评价吧。

《海伦》是一款已经被人们忽略了的、极好玩的游戏。从人设、音乐，再到系统、情节，《海伦》都有着RPG Maker系的同类所没有的一种清丽脱俗的气质。
然而这样的一款游戏在国内知名度之低至今依然是一个不解之谜。因而这次评奖我毫不犹豫在"在这游戏火之前我就慧眼识游戏"大奖一栏选了《海伦》，希望藉此多些人会接触到这款游戏。

此外，我有些许想向作者申请帮忙汉化这游戏。谁有这个志愿一起来？[/strike]

------2017.1.4------
汉化版发布后游戏终于火起来了！
拖了半年多社区攻略也终于完成了……
[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765152922]《海伦的神秘城堡 | 不可思议之城的海伦》攻略[/url]
我这拖延的潜能确实超出想象啊。
(,,•́ . •̀,,)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997298500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1470845575}
review:
A unique combat system, a simple, yet interesting story and a girl that can only talk through "?" and "!".

I had a very pleasant surprise with this game. I expected a normal RPG experience and was totally thrown out of it with how fast the story starts and how the combat system presented itself. I won't talk much about the combat system, you should see a gameplay video or just try it yourself to understand how good and refreshing it is. The exploration was nice as well, even if the game wasn't that big. It also has a secret dungeon, harder than the entire game, along with some other secrets.

If you enjoy RPG experiences from the SNES era, you simply have to try this game. It's like a throwback to older games, keeping their charm but still feeling new and refreshing. And when it goes on sale, you will have no reason for not trying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066443581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1493856606}
review: Really fun and unique battle system, and overall a charming game! Easily worth more than 2 dollars!

author: {'steamid': '76561198019292419', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1470590666}
review:
This is the indie equivalent of the classic SNES JRPG games. Shorter and with less story and depth, but supremely satisfying turn/wait based combat that is unique for every mob and boss. A lot of thought went into this game and it shows. There are more than 20 items (weapon/shield/magic/passive) including some "uniques", but you can only carry 8 at a time, so your loadout makes a huge difference. Helen doesn't level up, but her items do, and she gains health in various ways as you progress.

There are also two? endings... I got the lame ending first because I couldn't figure out what she means by "!" and "?" (!=yes, ?=no). Reloaded my save and finished up with the real ending... loved it! There were a few other times I feel I might have missed out on some extra little tidbits. Make sure to read everything (once you can read), and talk to everyone (also the fairy when she is with you).

author: {'steamid': '76561198009811282', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1470281439}
review: Fun game, and excellent value! Took me about 8 hours to finish, which is about the length of your average full $60 AAA games these days. Really goes to show you the sad state of the games industry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073904965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1470094712}
review:
Helen's Mysterious Castle is a minimalistic, straightforward RPG following the titular Helen's quest to...explore and find out more about the world around her, I guess. Eh, the story isn't bad, just really, really forgettable. The presentation is stock RPG Maker material, but is perfectly fine and I quite enjoyed the majority of the music tracks.

The battle system is easily the highlight of the game, and the most unique aspect of it; though not immediately intuitive, once you "get" it you should immediately admire the brilliance of it. It doesn't really take away some of the more grindy aspects of the game, though - it merely transfers the burden from character leveling to item leveling.

It's a very low asking cost for the few hours it'll provide, but outside of the battle system you aren't missing anything by skipping on the game. Decide accordingly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978795394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1468777534}
review:
Helen's Mysterious Castle is a quaint and short game. Very short. About six hours short. But that's not why I'm not recommending the game. I'm not going to recommend the game, despite the very cheap price point, due to the fact that it doesn't feel fleshed out.

You start off the game with almost no idea of what to do. How do controls work? Where are my menu options? What key presses do I need to do? How is my controller mapped? I probably spent half an hour going, "Ok... wtf?" You kind of run into that through out the game, as it does a poor job of explaining itself to you. The only thing it really goes into depth with is the combat system. If it didn't, I would have instantly refunded the game.

Furthermore, the story isn't very compelling.  You start off as an illiterate mute. You can't read any signs and can only respond with either "?" or "!". That's not engaging for me. The illteracy is fixed later via plot progression, but then you realize it was done that way to pretty much artificially inflate the length of the game. Some exposition of the story as you go wouldn't have ruined the game. For sure how it starts out would have had to change, but hey, how you start out is terrible anyway.

Otherwise this game is very much a classic JRPG. You know what? If it wasn't for the fact that this game was grind heavy, it probably would only be a couple hours long. This game is bad. Dont' buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104108015', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1469308705}
review:
Such a marvellous little RPG!

General Overview:
It's not a very long game, nor is it too challenging if you know what you're doing. The game mechanics work really well, being turn- AND Wait-based. Wait-based? Yes! The Wait gauge telling you how long you have to "wait" until you can execute your move. Being fast usually means hitting less hard, but being quick can result in the opponent doing some serious damage.

Story:
The story is a bit lacking. Took me a while to figure out I was a monster, living with monsters that look like humans. The game is pretty linear, and so is the story, but it can be difficult to figure out just where to go and what to do next. There's not much character development either.

Inventory:
Your inventory is limited to eight items, be it weapons or gear. If you collect an item, that you later wish to drop, just drop it. It is "collected" by one of the NPC's and you can easily get it back. The weapons and spells are pretty cool, but the Heal-spell is a bit of a let down. It decreases a level every time you use it outside of a battle, meaning you have to upgrade it again.

Leveling:
You don't level. Your character, Helen, doesn't get stronger. The EXP you earn are instead used for leveling and upgrading weapons and spells. That's a pretty interesting and unique idea for a game made with RPG-Maker! Throughout the story, you'll be able to find Health Bonuses, boosting your Max HP with a few HP. The steaks you get when you die, help a bit too, but only to a certain extent.

Visuals:
This game looks wonderful! It's made in RPG-Maker, but it looks so much better and more customised than any other RPG-Maker game I've played before. The characters look cute, you can actually open cupboards and every monster is represented by an overworld sprite and a portrait.

Music:
Standard music, but nice tunes. In the credits, all songs are credited, which leaves me to assume they come from the free music database. That doesn't make them any less fun to listen to though! ^ u^

Controls:
Really easy to use. Just use the arrows to walk and Z and X for other actions, hold Shift to run and you're good to go. Don't accidentally hit the F12 key to make a screenshot, it brings you back to the Title Screen... That happens to some people, you know >///>

Overall Opinion:
A wonderful, short, fun and exiting RPG to play, that can be challenging at times, but never too much to make you stop playing it. I've read some reports of the game crashing, but I haven't even encountered a glitch, other than the music not always starting when you reload.

Get this game, it's fairly cheap and a lot of fun to play! It also comes with seven Trading Cards!! ^ u^

author: {'steamid': '76561198019106150', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1467587281}
review:
Length: Around 5 - 8 hours

Pros:
-Refreshing combat system, simple to learn, enjoyable to the end
-Rather nice soundtrack (MIDI quality suits the aesthetic rather well, but you may disagree)
-Some memorable characters, seemingly influenced by Undertale
--Main protagonist still has some personality considering she is mute
-Nostalgic tilesets and graphics
-Simple but addicting upgrade system, although a little lacking in depth

Cons:
-Story is predictable; you'll know where it is going as soon as hints are given
-Soundtrack loops are occasionally too short and become annoying
-A few level design layout quirks with finding doors and exits

In short, for their first game (as far as I can find online) it is good - especially at such a cheap price - and if you enjoy any RPG or fantasy, you'll enjoy this. Hopefully it will see a sequel.
